title: Will al-Shabaab attack a US diplomatic facility in Africa before 1 July 2018?
preds:
No attacks on U.S. diplomatic facilities by al-Shabaab during Ramadan - 11 days left. Looking at the circumstances relating to the death of the U.S. special forces soldier. The activity would’ve attracted attention from al-Shabaab as 800 SNSF and KDF were conducting a multi-day operation, therefore carrying the potential for a high number of casualties. 
https://www.defense.gov/News/Article/Article/1545771/attack-in-somalia-kills-us-service-member-wounds-others/
Two days following the attack a VBIED was used at the same military base. 
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-somalia-security/suicide-car-bomb-in-somalia-injures-seven-soldiers-idUSKCN1J601G
It's possible that the U.S. diplomatic facilities will be on heightened alert as a result of the attack on U.S. forces. 
However, given that there have been no recent security messages from the U.S. embassy in Nairobi, this suggests there hasn't been an imminent threat made against diplomatic personnel, as had occurred in Somalia in November 2017.
adjusting down for passage of time

Had it here since first forecast. Knew consensus was kinda low. Going to re-eval tonight.
https://sofrep.com/104381/breaking-us-special-forces-attacked-in-somalia-by-al-shabab/

WoC@5% which is basically a rounding error here. Can I go negative 100?  Trumpy got a massive uphill battle if it is attacked given the funding cuts to State. But I imagine Fox will just blame it on Hillary somehow anyway. Bigly! NairobiGhazi 2.0! #Kenyazi? Sad. Bad.
They are not likely to attack since they don't seem to be interested in having the US AFRICOM expanding operations in Africa at this point

There probably will not be an attack by al-Shabaab against a US diplomatic facility in Africa before 1 July 2018. Location: The only two US diplomatic missions in the region are in Kenya (Nairobi) and Ethiopia (Addis Ababa), however al-Shabaab only has a presence in eastern Kenya. Time: There are only two months left to the question, however the US has become more active (militarily) in the region and we are entering the rainy fighting season.  Trends: al-Shabaab attacks against diplomatic facilities are trending downward from their previous peaks of 5 in 2013, 6 in 2014, 4 in 2015, and 1 in 2016. These attacks were almost exclusivity directed against UN and AMISOM facilities. (Global Terrorism Database)

Update of prior forecast at https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/694163. Since half of the remaining time has elapsed since that initial forecast, halve the probability of the event occurring.  (Assuming, as I do, that the assumptions that underpinned the original forecast have not changed.)

https://www.cnn.com/2018/04/19/politics/africa-isis-al-qaeda-threat/index.html The biggest al Qaeda affiliate is al Shabaab in Somalia where the terror group commands some 4,000-6,000 active fighters, according to the US military, making it one of al Qaeda's largest affiliates.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  I was surprised to read how many active fighters al-Shabaab has and was tempted to increase my forecast, but afterI read back through posts by @AB747 and @Ken_Barns, I'm cautiously optimistic that there won't be an attack before this question closes.  One key fact, I think, is that it seems (according to @Ken_Barns) that there's only one US diplomatic facility in the area in which al-Shabaab is active:  the embassy in Nairobi, Kenya.
Must have been drinking last night.  :D  Going back to the original forecast for now while I do more research.
+raising on recent increase in activity and a bad feeling about this
The situation is worsening and a coordinated retaliation for the January 19th raids is a looming specter.   https://www.cfr.org/interactives/global-conflict-tracker#!/conflict/al-shabab-in-somalia

Attacks seem to have occured at least yearly since 2014. The attacks don't seem to focus on typically western targets however alignment with Al Qaeda or a response to US drone strikes may  change this history.

reiterating forecast given short time frame, lack of US embassy in Somalia, and Al Shabaab's history - it appears they've never attacked a US facility. found this though and it reminded me that drone attacks on al shabaab might be strengthening the organization more than they hurt it https://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/opinion/trump-decree-killing-innocent-civilians-somalia-180114091717319.html

Maintaining forecast:  Haven’t found any updated information r.e. construction of U.S. embassy in Somalia. Al-Shabaab are continuing to attack AU troops:
“Al-Shabaab militants attacked an AU peacekeeper base in the town of Bulamarer, 130 km SW of the Mogadishu on April 1.” (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-somalia-security/al-shabaab-attacks-an-african-union-base-in-somalia-idUSKCN1H815F)  criticalthreats.org issued a ‘threat update’: “al-Shabaab conducted five coordinated operations, including complex explosive attacks, outside of Mogadishu. The political crisis has drawn security forces into Mogadishu and will likely stall counter al-Shabaab operations outside of the capital, further limiting the federal governments reach into southern and central Somalia.” 
(https://www.criticalthreats.org/briefs/threat-update/continuing-iranian-protests-may-pose-an-internal-security-threat-to-regime)

The US does not, at this time, appear to be a priority target for al-Shabaab and there are relatively few diplomatic facilities that are good candidates for an attack given the relatively focused geographic area of operations for al-Shabaab.

There is only a 3% chance that al-Shabaab will be a serious threat to U.S. personnel in Africa. Using the security dilemma theory as an analytical model, one can predict that the U.S will not act on al-Shabaab unless they feel highly insecure. Although al-Shabaab is not a state actor, this same model can still be loosely applied to terrorist organizations. By extension, due unreciprocal power parities, the U.S. wont attack unless they believe that al-Shabaab will attack them. Furthermore, al-Shabab is aware of its power condition relative to U.S, so if we were to assume that rationality implicates value maximization, then it would not be rational for them to attack an American facility in Africa. U.S' fear mostly lies in the possibility of a domestic attack (or an inspired attack).

take a look at this I think I found one of Al Shabaab's outposts on Facebook https://www.facebook.com/Al-shabaab-Military-558242910992134/ Should I just ask them whether they plan to attack the US embassy in Nairobi?

According to www.criticalthreats.org there is an ongoing political crisis between Somali Prime Minister Hassan Ali Khaire and Lower House Speaker Mohamed Osman Jawari which has led to the deployment of security forces to the parliaments Lower House.
(https://www.criticalthreats.org/briefs/gulf-of-aden-security-review)  There have been several attacks by al-Shabaab in the last 10 days, e.g.:
https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-somalia-blast/suicide-car-bomb-kills-three-near-somali-parliament-idUKKBN1H10M8
https://af.reuters.com/article/africaTech/idAFL8N1R45EK The increase in attacks could be as a result of a statement (the first of 2018) released by Al-Qaeda leader, Ayman al Zawahiri “urging muslims in East Africa to participate in jihad”. 
“Zawahiri outlined East African history in the ‘southern battle front of Islam” against European conquest.”
He also “encouraged East African muslims to fight the corrupt leadership on the battlefields in their regions and to kill apostates.” 
(https://www.criticalthreats.org/briefs/gulf-of-aden-security-review#_ftn5)  Increasing by 1%, however, the current political situation in Somalia could make them more vulnerable to attacks as opposed to a US diplomatic facility.
Decreasing forecast from 5% to 2%. Reviewed a list of AS' attacks and they haven't targeted the US.  Instead they go for mostly government targets in Somalia and Kenya.  Also target UN frequently.

Demoralized. 
Losing to transitional federals.
fighting with militant sunni's. 
defocusing; attention more local. Attempting to spread this as a war between christians and muslims - suggests they will choose softer targets, especially while their cadre of leaders winnowed.

Don't we have few embassies in Somalia? Also, haven't most of AS's attacks been on non-US related targets? On the other hand, the US has been drone striking AS.. makes the US a little more of a target.

I'm not sure the situation has escalated to this point yet- where this action from al-Shabaab would most likely be prompting significant retaliation from the United States, especially since it is a diplomatic facility and not a military outpost/base. However, the notable presence and activity of these groups in Africa leaves room for the possibly.

They have been weaken in recent period and do not have a strong army to attack a US facility, they can sure attack others but US facilities are hard to penetrate, therefore, they would not stupidly go for it.

Attack on an AMISOM facility:
“Al Shabaab militants fired several mortar rounds at a military base belonging to AMISOM in Lower Shabelle.” (http://allafrica.com/stories/201803050530.html)  “Al-Shabaab roadside IEDs killed HirShabelle State MP Ahmed Abdi Farah and Southwest State Security Minister Abdulkadir Abdirahman Baraf as they traveled with bodyguards from Baledogle Airport to Mogadishu”
This comes after an AMISOM spokesman warned that “al-Shabaab would increase attacks on government targets as AMISOM and SNA forces reopen supply roads connecting Mogadishu to central and southern Somalia.” 
(https://www.criticalthreats.org/briefs/gulf-of-aden-security-review)
These reopened roads are softer targets and enable al-Shabaab to target Somali politicians.  USAID Fact Sheet on Somalia March 6 2018: https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/03.06.18%20-%20USAID-DCHA%20Somalia%20Complex%20Emergency%20Fact%20Sheet%20%232.pdf

If Shabaab attacks a US facility this year, I would guess it would be somewhere they have not struck before, like Djibouti or the Gulf. I suspect if Al Shabaab attack at all it will be in the US, through US-based sympathizers.
Increasing slightly due to recent attack on French embassy, plus ISIS targeting US embassies in Middle East

It seems highly unlikely that a US diplomatic facility in Africa will be attacked in the next 4 months by al-Shabaab. Although the organization is still very much active in Somalia and the surrounding region, in the past staging deadly attacks in Kenya and Uganda, al-Shabaab has never attacked a US diplomatic facility. Many US air strikes on al-Shabaab targets since Trump took office have succeeded in killing hundreds of militants. Additionally, African Union forces remain active in Somalia to counter Al-Shabaab. Despite these facts, a chance of an attack on US diplomatic facilities does exist. Al-Shabaab is ideologically opposed to the West and thus may counter the increase in US involvement with a direct attack. Another possible path to attack on US diplomatic facilities could pan out as African Union troops continue to pull out of Somalia. With the Somalian government still weak and disorganized, al-Shabaab could regain former territories and increase its presence and power in the region, putting all targets, including US diplomatic facilities, at increased risk. However, given the short time frame for this question, the chances of attack are extremely low.  https://www.cfr.org/backgrounder/al-shabab

Maintaining forecast: “The Troop Contributing Countries to AMISOM and the Federal Government of Somalia want the troop draw down exercise which started last December halted.” 
“The leaders observed that the timeframe and troop levels under the UN Security Council Resolution are not realistic and would lead to a reversal of gains made by AMISOM over the years to defeat the terrorist group.” 
“The summit also noted that the drawdown undermined the capacity of AMISOM to deliver on its mandate, the inadequate capacity of the SNA and the importance of hastening the formation of the Somali national security forces.” 
(http://amisom-au.org/2018/03/somali-somalia-and-troop-contributing-countries-call-for-a-halt-to-amisom-troop-reduction/)  No scheduled meeting at the UNSC r.e. AMISOM in March: http://www.un.org/en/sc/inc/pages/pdf/pow/powmonthly.pdf
The UN Secretary General’s report on the future of funding for AMISOM is due March 2018.
Decreasing to a more socially acceptable probability level but still maintaining high alert status.

Very informative report from the CTC at West Point: ‘Targeted Terror: the Suicide Bombers of al-Shabaab’ (https://ctc.usma.edu/app/uploads/2018/02/Targeted-Terror-3.pdf)  Note: There are some limitations to the data set; the method used to collect the data is “less adept at capturing local-level, non-national newspapers” and they “did not capture any articles not written in English”  “Our data shows that al-Shabaab suicide bombers’ most frequent targets are:
Personnel and symbols of the Somali state (Somali government and security sector officials as well as Somali government buildings and institutions) to which it deployed 36.6% of its suicide bombers.
Personnel and symbols of the international community (officials and personnel of AMISOM, the AU or UN) to which it deployed 24.5% of its suicide bombers.
Spaces where personnel in two demographics tend to congregate (hotels and restaurants), to which it deployed 32.4% of its suicide bombers Between September 2006 and October 2017 
7 attackers sent to non-Somali government institutions
21 attackers send to AU institutions
8 attackers sent to UN institutions
17 attackers targeting UN/AMISOM/AU/Non-Somali personnel  Targeting physical international institutions (AU and or UN) struck physical locations of these international institutions in 12.4% of attempted attacks.  Al-Shabaab suicide attacks in Kenya: “Al-Shabaab has sent at least nine suicide bombers to undertake operations in Kenya, though each have either failed to reach their target or have been arrested well before the planned operation. Majority arrested in Nairobi, while both Mombasa and Wajir have seen attempted plots. 
Also information on al-Shabaab suicide attacks in Uganda, Djibouti and Ethiopia. 
Kenyan police foil al-Shabaab attack on Nairobi (http://allafrica.com/stories/201802180153.html)  Note there is no direct reference to United States.

Feels like al-Shabaab is the muscle of East Africa (on land AND/OR on sea). What services can al-Shabaab perform, who would they perform them for, and how can they be paid (what can they sell/use/trade)? Logistics (and sanctions) is key here: http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-02/26/c_137001557.htm
 http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-02/22/c_136992152.htm
 http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-02/25/c_136997422.htm Editing to add links, will probably make a new, more detailed forecast, very soon.  Interactive (Global)  Map of US Diplomatic Facilities: https://diplomacy.state.gov/discoverdiplomacy/explorer/#places Lots of upcoming elections as well as resignations/appointments that are currently going on: 
1. Libya, http://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-43198444 , 
2. Sierra Leone elections (march 7th):http://www.thesierraleonetelegraph.com/west-african-elections-observers-arrive-in-freetown/
3. Ethiopia (less than a week) :http://www.africanews.com/2018/02/24/ethiopia-s-ruling-eprdf-sets-congress-date-new-pm-latest-march-3//
Don't really know all activities of al-Shabaab.  So while possibilities of attack exist, al-Shabaab seems to attack African activities, not foreign.

While it's likely Al-Shabaab would strike a US diplomatic facility if they could, given the current circumstances (pressure on the organization evidenced by its retraction into Somalia, no manned American missions in Somalia), it seems unlikely that they would invest the effort when there are plenty of locally available targets. Assuming al-Shabaab was intent on striking a US diplomatic facility with Americans inside - which is plausible given the precedent for attacking UN missions in Somalia - their closest available target is the diplomatic mission to Kenya in Nairobi. The last time al-Shabaab carried out a credited attack there was the Westgate Shopping Mall incident in 2013 and an incident on the street in 2012 when a member reportedly threw a grenade into a moving bus. It seems more likely Al-Shabaab would attack those forces that are currently attacking it, e.g. AMISOM, Somali Army, etc.
Al-Shabaab is sort of territorially limited.  getting access to a us mission might be difficult.  Nairobi woudl be most likely.

Harakat al-Shabaab al-Mujahideen, more commonly known as al-Shabaab, a jihadist fundamentalist group based in East Africa pledged allegiance to the militant Islamist organization Al-Qaeda in 2012. This group has been causing problems in Africa. Their demands and their ideology is deeply rooted from Al-Qaida's ideology. Recent reporting indicates a high probability that this group will be planning an attack against US facilities in Africa as a show of existence and capability.

I think it is very likely to happen.  There is so much internal focus in this country now on the Russia/Trump investigation and the FBI and Justice departments that I think al-Shabaab will think it a good time to do such an attack.  I further believe it will be in a smaller country, one that most people dont even know much if anything about.

al-Shabaab will get bigger and better; Ethiopia close by; OBOR maritime road location https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/11/africa-command-conducts-air-strikes-somalia-171103202800400.html
http://www.atimes.com/article/china-establish-court-obor-disputes/
https://www.redanalysis.org/2017/01/30/chinese-new-silk-road-east-africa/

DEFINITIONS
"al-Shabaab" = Organised group attacks claimed by al-Shabaab would definitely count.  "Lone wolf" attacks where either the lone wolf, or al-Shabaab itself, credit al-Shabaab with the attack would _probably_ count.  Attacks attributed to al-Shabaab by a nation's officials, where al-Shabaab declaims responsibility _might_ count. "Attack" = any attempted violence where the target is a US diplomatic facility.  The attempted violence must already have started, so the interception of a planned attack would not.  However, an attack that results in violence where the violence is halted short of the diplomatic facility itself _might_ count (eg. a raid that results in a firefight with roadblock forces a few hundred metres away from the facility). "US diplomatic facility" = "Any Foreign Service establishment maintained by the US Department of State abroad", as defined by the Department of Defense.  Generally only includes consulates and embassies, but more vaguely defined "liaison offices" may count too.  By a tight definition, the US has no "diplomatic facility" in Somalia, but but a broad definition, offices being used by the "US Mission to Somalia" _might_ count.  Technically, attacks on US diplomatic staff who are not in a "US diplomatic facility" should not count. THOUGHTS
al-Shabaab is an organisation whose activities mostly take place in Somalia, Yemen, and the Somali-populated areas of Kenya: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_Al-Shabaab_related_events.  That said, they have been able to strike at soft civilian targets in Kenya. There are many US diplomatic facilities in Africa (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_diplomatic_missions_of_the_United_States), but the only one anywhere near the al-Shabaad area of operations is the embassy in Nairobi.  IF al-Shabaab attacks a US diplomatic facility, it is most likely to be this one ... and that is a fairly hard target: it was rebuilt after a bombing in 1998 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Embassy_of_the_United_States,_Nairobi).  Indeed, US embassies in general have become much harder targets since 2001 (http://www.allgov.com/departments/department-of-state/bureau-of-overseas-buildings-operations?agencyid=7185). Given NO al-Shabaab attacks on ANY diplomatic facilities in the last 10 years, I find it difficult to see that al-Shabaab will start to target diplomatic facilities within the next 6 months and, if they do, why they would start with distant and highly defended US facilities? *********************************
After roughly formulating the above, I have reviewed others' forecasts on this question.  I especially thank @AB747 for her very detailed postings: her rather more comprehensive assessment concords with my impression.

The allied forces have ramped up offensives against the militants as the African Union forces continue with the draw-down which started with 500 troops last December.
http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-02/15/c_136978126.htm
maybe they decide to need attention over North Korea

The 2018 Worldwide Threat Assessment of the US Intelligence Community states: “Somalia’s recently elected government probably will struggle to protect its authority and implement security reforms amid the drawdown of AU forces in 2018, while al-Shabaab - the most potent terrorist threat to US interests in East Africa - probably will increase attacks.” 
(https://www.dni.gov/files/documents/Newsroom/Testimonies/2018-ATA---Unclassified-SSCI.pdf?utm_source=Join+the+Community+Subscribers&utm_campaign=e937f10cc7-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2018_02_14&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_02cbee778d-e937f10cc7-122637085&mc_cid=e937f10cc7&mc_eid=582d9de4fe)  The February 8, Gulf of Aden Security Review states: “Al-Shabaab has increased attacks targeting security forces on the road linking Afgoye to Mogadishu in recent weeks” 
February 9, Gulf of Aden Security Review: “Al-Shabaab has targeted several Kenyan convoys with IEDs in north east Kenya near the Somali border in recent weeks.” 
https://www.criticalthreats.org/briefs/gulf-of-aden-security-review#_ftn5  The map shown in this CNN article shows that al-Shabaab control the road west of Afgoye to Baidoa, whereby the group taxes each truck at $800. 
“The extraction of tolls at roadblocks was one of the biggest sources of money for al-Shabaab.” 
“The African Union military leadership admits that it can’t push al-Shabaab off the major roads that provide it with so much income.” 
“This leaves a growing number of American troops shouldering the ever-increasing security burden in Somalia” 
(https://edition.cnn.com/2018/02/12/africa/somalia-al-shabaab-foreign-aid-intl/index.html)  Maintaining a low forecast, as given the security situation, it would likely be easier for al-Shabaab to attack military convoys, including U.S. personnel, along the main roads which they control, rather than target a diplomatic facility.
No capability to mount out of area operations

There hasn't been an attack on a US diplomatic mission in Africa since September 2012 when there were attacks in Libya and Tunisia.  Before that, the last attacks were in 1998.  Of the many attacks against US diplomatic missions the majority occur in the MIddle East or South Asia.  Even though Al Shabaab is increasing its operational intensity in recent months, their activities are confined almost exclusively to Somalia and small sections of Kenya and Ethiopia on the borders.  The likelihood of an Al-Shabab attack on US diplomatic facilities is low because the nearest of these are at least 300 miles away from the nearest areas of Al-Shabab operation.

What constitutes an attack and what constitutes a US diplomatic facility? Seems like a relatively low bar even with the organizational and time line limits. Would be curious to see methodologies for how people got to 0-10% probabilities

Maintaining forecast. Interesting statistical summary on violent events linked to African Militant Islamist groups in 2017: https://africacenter.org/spotlight/activity-fewer-fatalities-linked-african-militant-islamist-groups-2017/
"Al Shabaab continues to be linked to the highest escalation of violence. It was involved in more than three times the number of violent events related to militant islamist groups in Africa than the next most active group, Boko Haram (1,593 vs 500 respectively)"

The US campaign against Al-Shabaab has increased during the last few years. The number of U.S. troops and the number of U.S. airstrikes inside of Somalia last year both dramatically increased. Despite the rise in U.S. actions, AS has shown little desire to strike any U.S. positions, especially diplomatic positions anywhere in Africa. They seem to remain focused on their own struggles inside the country against the Central government over control of the future of the country. Additionally, outside of Somalia, AS has remained focused on attacking neighboring countries, such as Kenya and Ethiopia, who have provided aid and support to the government. Although unlikely, an attack remains possible especially as the U.S. continues to ramp up operations against AS and other radical groups throughout Africa. As the number of missions and troops against these groups increase throughout  Africa, the more likely an attack against the U.S. may be. However, that attack would likely be against U.S. forces and not a diplomatic mission.

Recent coalition efforts to reduce al-Shabaab (AS) capability in the region appear to be effective in the near term. Expanded US authority to target AS throughout Somalia includes an increase in drone strikes, special operations raids, and the coalition appears to receive relevant and timely intelligence as to AS operations facilitating disruption. One example is the freeing of child conscript soldiers from an AS training camp in recent weeks temporarily disrupting the group's recruitment operations. Furthermore, as US diplomatic facilities and security agencies have accumulated time evaluating the threat from AS, it is possible the risk of successful attack has decreased. It also cannot be understated the cooperation amongst coalition security agencies in recent years.

I chose to take on the question “will al-Shabaab attack a US diplomatic facility in Africa before 1 July 2018?”  I am predicting that the likelihood of this event occurring is at 1%.  Al-Shabaab has had some success in targeting Western entities; however, the last successful bombing of US embassies occurred in 1998 in Kenya and Tanzania.  Americans living in Africa and staffers at embassies are very aware of the potential danger and are taking all precautions to secure themselves and the embassies in the region.  It is highly unlikely that an attack will occur in the next five months.
https://ke.usembassy.gov/al-shabaab-threats-to-western-and-kenyan-targets/

Not point to it from their perspective--no discernible upside and substantial possible downside.  Besides, the way things are going there mayn't be any US diplomatic facilities in Africa by then.   M. Petits-Doigts is probably unsure why we should have any facilities in countries of That Sort.  As managerial neglect and budget cuts kick in, he will doubtless shift all our diplomatic facilities to countries like Norway.  You know, the nice places....

As their finances become more strained, their desperation grows and the AU steps back and the US escalates it’s presence in the region, al-Shabaab looking for a way to strike back at the US makes sense.

The U. S. drone strikes against the Al Shabaab in Somalia are “eradicating” these jihadist militants, said the head of the African Union mission in the country (Amisom) on Friday.
http://www.africanews.com/2018/01/27/drones-to-wipe-out-al-shabaab-in-somalia/

Maintaining forecast:
A recent report by the International Crisis Group on “Priorities for the African Union in 2018” stated: “Despite the gathering pace of an AMISOM military offensive in Southern Somalia, backed by U.S. airstrikes. The AU mission, itself underfunded, suffers from low troop morale and is scheduled to pull out by the end of 2020” 
“Looming withdrawal comes at a time of heightened tensions between Mogadishu and Somalia’s Federal Regions. During the 2017 Gulf Crisis, Saudi Arabia and the UAE put pressure on Somali President Mohamed to pick sides by breaking diplomatic relations with Qatar. His attempt to steer a neutral course led the UAE to ramp up support and appeal directly to the federal governments, as a counterweight to Mogadishu.” 
(https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/b135-seven-priorities-for-the-au-in-2018.pdf)  Michael Keating, the UN Secretary-General’s Special Representative for Somalia, told a Security Council briefing “A serious danger exists that long-standing disputes between Puntland and Somaliland, and in particular an armed stand off in Sool, could erupt into violence in the coming days.
(http://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=58470#.WmoYVEysOfU) 
Fighting between the government’s will not help the offensive to eradicate al-Shabaab and could give al-Shabaab the room to grow again.  A Guardian Investigation “found that dozens of civilians have been killed and wounded in Somalia as U.S.-led airstrikes have increased to unprecedented levels.” 
Particularly noting: “The strikes have also killed large numbers of livestock and caused extensive damage done to agricultural infrastructure” (https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/jan/23/somali-citizens-count-cost-of-surge-in-us-airstrikes-under-trump). As Keating also said when talking about efforts to address deficits that lend extremism a degree of credibility “These deficits include corruption, lack of education and job opportunities for young people, weak national justice and corrections capacity, and grievances from unresolved disputes.” (http://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=58470#.WmoYVEysOfU)
A country at risk of famine combined with the destruction of agricultural livelihoods plays into al-Shabaab’s propaganda and may increase the groups credibility.  Apologies if any one has referenced these articles before: 
Found this article by the Combating Terrorism Center at West Point on al-Shabaab’s IED capabilities: https://ctc.usma.edu/foreign-technology-or-local-expertise-al-shabaabs-ied-capability/
“According to a recent IED assessment, about 60% of the explosives contained in al-Shabaab attacks along the Kenyan border come from counterterrorism forces, obtained either from sub-munitions dropped by Kenyan war planes or through plunder of the AMISOM.” 
“Al-Shabaab’s IEDs are becoming more deadly and complex, but the growing impact of attacks comes not just from imported technology, but also from innovative deployment…The key evolution is al-Shabaab has become more adept in its deployment of bombs, tailoring its IED attacks through refined tactics, techniques and procedures.” 
Related: “Senior defectors provide operational intelligence - such as how al-Shabaab makes armoured vehicle bomb - and insight into leadership” https://www.reuters.com/article/us-somalia-defections-exclusive/exclusive-somalia-lures-defectors-in-new-push-against-insurgents-idUSKBN1FD0KO  2016 report from the Bureau of Diplomatic Security: https://www.state.gov/documents/organization/273987.pdf - this report explains the ‘High Threats Program’

while they are a spent force there is a good chance that the combat air strikes allowed under the new US government rules may removing the threat of  retaliatory air strikes may  remove the barrier that lead to al- Shabaab launching fewer attacks now that they are going to be hit regardless of there actions they may increase the frequency of there strikes against the Great Devil as its now a lose lose situation for them.
Lowering to 2%. Possible but Al-Shabaab a mostly spent force. They don’t have a lot of “wins”. They may go unconventional but limited abilities...
Puts them to high on the USA Git list of Terrorist orgs. After Daesh success, Terrorist will rethink direct confrontations with the West.

After news of Somali Prime Minister Hassan Ali Khayre sacking his ministers for foreign affairs, the interior and commerce. The article also brought to attention the posts of ‘Head of National Security' and ‘Police Commander’ are still to be filled. (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-somalia-government/somalia-pm-sacks-three-ministers-as-country-battles-insurgency-idUSKBN1ET0JR)
Somalia owes $4 billion in debt, which is preventing the country from “accessing new funds from the IMF or the International Development Association, the soft loan arm of the World Bank that has money earmarked specifically for fragile states”. 
“Mr. Khayre said the government had a budget of $247 million which was not enough to create the social programmes needed to prevent radicalisation of unemployed youth or to address deprivation. He could not confirm an estimate that al-Shabaab had a bigger budget than the government.” 
“Head of the Atlantic Council Africa Centre in Washington Peter Pham said: “he was not convinced that corruption has been brought under control ‘huge amounts of aid in cash simply disappears,’ adding that he suspected up to half of the 27,000 soldiers being paid to fight al-Shabaab with western help were “ghost soldiers” drawing a salary without doing any fighting” (https://www.ft.com/content/142e8e9a-f22c-11e7-ac08-07c3086a2625) 
With the top security posts not being filled and the possibility of thousands of ghost soldiers, they’re not encouraging signs for an improvement in security over the next 7 months. That being said, al-Shabaab attacks over the last week have been contained mostly to Somalia and the Kenya-Somali border, so no closer to Nairobi. 
(Update on Lamu Forest - http://allafrica.com/stories/201801120010.html)  The state department added Al-Shabaab member Abukar Ali Adan to the list of ‘Individuals and Entities Designated by the State Department under E.O. 13224’ (https://www.state.gov/j/ct/rls/other/des/143210.htm) 
“The order provides a means by which to disrupt the financial support network for terrorists and terrorist organisations by authorising the U.S. government to designate and block the assets of foreign entities that commit, or pose a significant risk of committing, acts of terrorism.” “The Order authorises the U.S. to block the assets of individuals and entities that provide support, services or assistance to, or otherwise associate with, terrorists and terrorist organisations designated under the order as well as their subsidiaries, front organisations, agents and associates.” 
(https://www.state.gov/j/ct/rls/other/des/122570.htm) 
It will be interesting to see whether this designation does any damages to their finances. There are 3 other names linked to Al-Shabaab on the list from 2014 and 2015, and that hasn’t prevented the group from growing.  Not sure the credibility of the source that Critical Threats has used with the January 11 GoA Security Review but going to throw it out there as something to potentially look for: “Al-Shabaab leadership fears that a large clan in Mogadishu and central Somalia plans to suspend ties with the group. Al Shabaab’s head of policy Hussein Ali Fidow attempted to rally support from Somali clan elders in Adan Yabaal, Middle Shabelle. (https://www.criticalthreats.org/briefs/gulf-of-aden-security-review#_ftn5)
Intent is present. Capability seems suspect. Vulnerability is unknown.

The Communique of the 741st PSC meeting on the situation in Somalia and the implementation of the mandate of the AU Mission in Somalia stated: “Notes with deep concern the growing capacity of al-Shabaab and its continued attacks against the innocent population, the symbols of the Federal Government and AMISOM personnel.” (http://www.peaceau.org/en/article/communique-of-the-741st-psc-meeting-on-the-situation-in-somalia-and-the-implementation-of-the-mandate-of-the-au-mission-in-somalia-amisom)

On the December 23: al-Shabaab shelled Villa Somalia (the presidential palace) and assassinated two government officials in Hamarweyne District. The militants also attacked a SNA barracks in Huriwa District and detonated an IED targeting the MoD and AMISOM convoy. 
Al-Shabaab militants stole a vehicle during a raid on the Ijara Police station in Garissa County, East Kenya on December 30.
On December 31: “Kenyan Defense Forces raided an al-Shabaab hideout on Boni forest area near the Somali-Kenyan border, killing five militants. The KDF recovered a cache of weapons and supplies in the hideout. A stolen Kenyan police vehicle filled with explosives detonated during the gunfight.
(https://www.criticalthreats.org/briefs/gulf-of-aden-security-review)  With the increasing capabilities of al-Shabaab and the type of weapons and machinery they are obtaining, it seems it could be within their capabilities to attack a U.S. diplomatic facility. Adjusting forecast: Somali parliamentarians have “threatened to impeach President Farmajo, accusing him of treason and violating the constitution. 96 lawmakers called for the speaker of parliament to reopen the session for impeachment proceedings which require 92 votes.” 
(https://www.criticalthreats.org/briefs/gulf-of-aden-security-review#_ftn5) 
An unstable government could put more pressure on Somali troops, coupled with the food insecurity and instability in the countries contributing to AMISOM, which would allow al-Shabaab to make more gains. One expects that if this was the case, the U.S. would adjust security at embassies (as was the case after the announcement of the embassy move to Jerusalem - https://www.stripes.com/news/marines-ready-to-deploy-in-wake-of-trump-s-jerusalem-announcement-1.501409)  Al-Shabaab have conducted seven attacks, so far, against Puntland security forces in December 2017. Most recent attack was an IED targeting a US-Puntland convoy (https://www.criticalthreats.org/briefs/gulf-of-aden-security-review#_ftn5)

“The U.S. Department of Defence submitted a two-year plan for its operations in Somalia. The plan will lift restrictions on personnel decisions and broaden strike authorisations loosened by President Trump.” (https://www.criticalthreats.org/briefs/gulf-of-aden-security-review/gulf-of-aden-security-review-december-11-2017#_ftn7) 
The NY Times went into further detail stating: “the plan would also exempt operations in Somalia from another default rule in Mr.Trump’s guidelines: that airstrikes be allowed only when officials have determined there is a near certainty that no civilians will be killed. Instead, the officials said, the plan calls for imposing a lower standard: reasonable certainty that no bystanders will die.” (https://www.nytimes.com/2017/12/10/world/africa/pentagon-somalia-combat-islamic-militants.html?_r=0) 
An increase in civilian casualties will play into the propaganda of al-Shabaab and IS, which could lead to a reduction in support for the Somali government, thus having detrimental consequences on the security forces. Especially when taking into account that the U.S. is suspending food and fuel aid for Somalia’s armed forces. A State Department official said: “During recent discussions between the U.S. and the Federal Government of Somalia, both sides agreed that the SNA had failed to meet the standards for accountability for U.S. assistance.” (https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-somalia-military-exclusive/exclusive-u-s-suspends-aid-to-somalias-battered-military-over-graft-idUKKBN1E81XW?il=0) A recent suicide attack at a police training camp in Mogadishu, which killed at least 18 officers, demonstrates the more likely target of an al-Shabaab attack. 
(https://www.reuters.com/article/us-somalia-security/suicide-bomber-kills-at-least-18-at-police-academy-in-somalias-capital-idUSKBN1E80GF?il=0). However, this article also highlights the possibility of a militant disguising as a friendly force and firing upon U.S. forces - considering that the U.S. work with AMISOM and the SNSF. 
That being said, an attack on a U.S. diplomatic facility, not U.S. forces, is the basis of this question.

The airstrike killed one combatant; “U.S. forces observed the al-Shabaab combatant participating in attacks on a U.S. and Somali convoy. U.S. forces subsequently conducted the strike under collective self defense authorities.” (http://www.africom.mil/media-room/pressrelease/30084/u-s-conducts-airstrike-in-support-of-the-federal-government-of-somalia) 
Robyn Mack, spokesperson for AFRICOM said “The attack on the convoy involved "ineffective" small arms fire and resulted in no US personnel being killed or wounded” (http://edition.cnn.com/2017/11/13/politics/us-strikes-yemen-somalia/index.html)  Brig. Richard Karemir, the military and defense spokesperson for Uganda, has said the country is willing to deploy (conditions-based) 5,000 troops to Somalia, outside of the AU and UN mandate. (http://intelligencebriefs.com/uganda-promises-5000-troops-to-somalia-to-fight-al-shabaab-in-the-wake-of-amisom-withdrawal/) 
Drawdown of AMISOM troops in Somalia is not currently supported by the U.S. gov: “We do not support further drawdown of forces beyond that level at this time, due to ongoing security concerns, a State Department official said. “The United States supports a conditions-based AMISOM drawdown that is tied to the standup of capable, professional Somali security forces.” (https://www.militarytimes.com/flashpoints/2017/11/09/amisom-withdrawal-tests-us-mission-in-somalia/)  Will watch for developments of the ISIS-Al-Shabaab relationship - any signs of working together could render the possibility of more elaborate attacks. Maintaining forecast:  In retaliation for the bombing in Mogadishu, the Somali government is reportedly launching a large-scale offensive against al-Shabaab: 
“A government official said another build up is taking place around Bale Dogle airport. “I cannot tell you more than that. But I can confirm that there will be a massive attack on al-Shabaab controlled areas and strongholds involving AMISOM and other international partners.” (https://www.voanews.com/a/officials-confirm-somalia-preparing-for-large-scale-offensive-against-al-shabab/4088460.html)  Without support from the Somali communities, the progress in the government’s anti al-Shabaab campaign is limited: 
A recent Reuters article stated: “across south-central Somalia, where better security is encouraging wealthy exiles who fled in the 1990s to return home - often igniting fresh land conflicts.” 
“The federal government is encouraging diaspora to come back, Somalia’s Information Minister Abdirahman Omar Osman told Reuters. The country needs their skills, knowledge and expertise.” 
“Few Somalis have faith in the judicial system, which is plagued by graft, or in the government, where both the president and prime minister are diaspora returnees.” “This is where al-Shabaab has far and away the greatest advantage on this land issue,” he said, as the militants are seen as less corrupt” 
(https://www.reuters.com/article/us-somalia-landrights-diaspora/back-to-the-land-friction-as-somali-exiles-return-home-idUSKBN1CH1YK)  However, after the recent bombing in Mogadishu, it’s possible that more somali’s will turn against the militant group, as thousands demonstrated against “those behind the bombings” (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-somalia-attacks-protests/somalis-defy-police-to-protest-against-deadly-truck-bombings-idUSKBN1CN13E)  Given the recent developments, I will be watching out for any changes in the U.S. military’s role in Somalia.

Lowering forecast after doing more research on U.S. diplomatic facilities in Somalia. 
The location of the proposed U.S. embassy will be at the Mogadishu International Airport Compound. The Bureau of Overseas Building Operations described access to the location as “extremely restricted” (https://govtribe.com/project/department-of-state-2017-design-build-construction-contract-for-somalia-interim-facility-mogadishu-somalia). The British Embassy in Somalia, which opened in 2014, is also located at the MIA compound, and was described as a “small compound within the heavily guarded barriers of Mogadishu International Airport” (https://www.theguardian.com/public-leaders-network/2014/may/22/britain-newest-embassy-mogadishu-somalia) 
Given the location of the compound, one would expect several checkpoints before gaining entry to the proposed embassy site. Reports on when the building is due to be finished are not consistent - we might have a better picture towards the end of the year.  Progress against al-Shabaab:
“SNA, in a well coordinated operation, managed to capture several areas and free civilian hostages from al-Shabaab militants.” 
“The operation was conducted near Baidoa town and its environs in the Bay Region” 
“Sidow Ali, Chief of Goof-Gaduud Burey said the operation would continue until all areas under al-Shabaab militants are freed completely” (http://intelligencebriefs.com/sna-capture-more-areas-from-al-shabaab-militants-in-bay-region/)

Raising forecast: 
Security forces are making progress in Operation Linda Boni:
“Officers conducting Operation Linda Boni in Lamu have discovered and destroyed 3 key al-Shabaab hideouts at Lango La Simba in Witu Division of Lamu West…More police and military camps have been set up in terror prone areas…” (http://allafrica.com/stories/201709120043.html)  The U.S. State Department issued a travel alert for U.S. Citizens residing or travelling to Kenya on September 27. “New elections on October 26, 2017 - Rallies, demonstrations, and protests may occur with little notice. As with all large events, there is opportunity for criminal elements or terrorists to target participants and visitors.” Though the travel alert does state: “There is no indication that U.S. citizens may be targets of violence.” (https://travel.state.gov/content/passports/en/alertswarnings/KenyaTravelAlert.html) 
One would expect the usual response to such an alert would be heightened security at the U.S. Embassy (Kenya) and immediate areas. 
This comes after the Kenyan National Intelligence Service warned of terrorism threats facing the country from al-Shabaab cells in Somalia and IS. (https://www.africanindy.com/news/kenyan-intelligence-warns-of-terrorism-threats-11290062)  Also increasing forecast due to a mention in a recent africom.mil press release referring to the “U.S. embassy standing up in Mogadishu” (http://www.africom.mil/media-room/article/29947/africom-delivers-equipment-for-strategic-partner-uganda). The state department still lists the U.S. mission to Somalia operating out of the U.S. embassy in Kenya, but this recent statement - and not being able to find any evidence to prove its false - suggests its possible that there is a U.S. diplomatic facility in Somalia. 
If this facility does exist, coupled with the fact that U.S. forces frequently conduct airstrikes in Somalia, the most recent being three precision airstrikes on September 13, killing six terrorists, (https://www.africom.mil/media-room/pressrelease/29909/u-s-conducts-airstrike-in-support-of-the-federal-government-of-somalia) would make it an easier-to-reach target, than the embassy in Kenya.

Lack of attention to diplomatic security

Consider this to be very unlikely, though I’m not discounting the spontaneity of terrorists. I agree with other forecasters that there are softer targets, therefore why go for a heavily secured facility in Nairobi. 
For example, Al-Shabaab ambushed Somali government and AU peacekeeping troops on the 30th July 2017, killing 23 AMISOM workers and 1 Somali soldier. (https://www.nytimes.com/reuters/2017/07/30/world/africa/30reuters-somalia-attacks-offical.html)   If al-Shabaab targets a single country, rather than an intra-governmental agency, the historical trend shows Kenya being the main target, due to the Kenyan government sending troops to Somalia as part of the African Union. 
“Al-Shabaab conducts regular attacks in Kenya, which they want to pressure into withdrawing its contingent from AMISOM.” (https://www.nytimes.com/reuters/2017/08/04/world/africa/04reuters-somalia-violence.html) 
Previous attacks also suggest Kenya is a target due to its majority Christian population.  Given that the U.S. Mission to Somalia is operated out of the US Embassy in Nairobi, al-Shabaab fighters would have to travel to the city, it has been done before with the Westgate attack, but again there are softer targets along the Kenya/Somali border. 
The upcoming Kenyan Presidential elections and increase in al-Shabaab-claimed attacks “presents a huge problem for Kenya’s security agencies…On election day security agencies will be strained while attempting to stop any possible violence and al-Shabaab could take advantage” (https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/jul/08/nine-kenyans-beheaded-by-somali-al-shabaab-terrorists). This, along with the recent U.S. conducted operation that targeted Ali Mohamed Hussein or Ali Jabal, could give al-Shabaab a reason to target the embassy. (http://www.reuters.com/article/us-somalia-security-idUSKBN1AK19F?il=0) 
However, the U.S. embassy is also situated on the same road as the United Nations so if there are adequate security measures in place, I would expect there to be a checkpoint for vehicles before you can get to the buildings, which would limit the opportunity for an attack.

The following data provides a provisional pattern of the activity of Al Shabaab, it's linkages to other organizations, number of incidents, deaths and wounded from 2006 - 2016.  Major acts of terrorism as an irregular tactic are considered while attacks on leaders of either the regime or the terror organizations are not counted. March 2007:    Adam Salaam Adam engages in an attack with a car bomb in a suicide attack against government soldiers;  73 killed, unknown wounded. October 2008:    Al Shabaab conducts five simultaneous suicide car bombs i n the cities of Haragisha and Bosasso targeting UNDP offices and government buildings.  All events occur within Somalia or Kenya July 2010:     Conducts two simultaneous suicide car bombs at an Ethiopian restaurant; 74 killed, 85+ wounded. June 2013:    Suicide bomber detonates a  car bomb at UNDP in Mogadishu.  Al Shabaab fighters enter the compound and engage security force;  22 killed, 20 wounded. September 2013:  Westgate Mall in Nairobi triggering a four day siege with Kenyan government forces; 68 killed, 70 wounded. May 2014:    Suicide bombers attack a restaurant in Djibouti (its first attack);  3 killed, 11 wounded. November 2014:     Attacks bus with  60 passengers traveling to Nairobi.  Executions of those who cannot recite the Q'uran; 28 killed, unknown wounded April 2015:     Gunmen attack Garissa Univeristy College; 151 killed, unknown wounded. During 1984 and 2017 there were 10 active terror organizations, with four of them ongoing to the present.   These are Al Aaeda, Al Shabaab, Ras Kamboui Movement and Ashli Sunna Wal Jamma.   Alliances, cooperation, resource and intelligence sharing are not unknown in the relationships among these terror organizations.  However this set of activity should only be considered periodic, as needed, and not permanent.  The relationship between Al Qaddafi and Al Shabaab are more complex and ongoing. This allows us to conclude that while there has been no activity on US installations in Africa by Al Shabaab, it is not impossible.  However, given the military asymmetry, US government security and intelligence apparatus and activity in the region, makes it virtually  impossible these days for AQ or Al Shabaab to engage to terror strategies against US installations, property or operations.
